As the competition began, the Yellow Falcons' representatives entered the stage and performed a piece related to the theme of being Filipino.




The Red Phoenix took the stage and performed a piece encouraging the preservation of Filipino traditions and culture despite modernization.




The Grade 7 Green Mockingjays went on stage and performed, competing against the Yellow Falcons and Red Phoenix for the championship.




The Blue Eagles performed with a style that featured distinct vocals and instrumentals.




Sir Joselito Menduez Almuete announced the Grade 9 Red Phoenix as the champions before the event concluded.




Red Phoenix representatives Schen Reece Mercado and Glacey Sebia expressed their reaction to the unexpected win. 




"I'm very happy because it's my first time joining a competition. When it came to making the song, it was really difficult because we only made it in one day, and we practiced it for only two days, so there was a lot of pressure. Winning was really unexpected." Sebia happily expressed.

  One of the events of this year's Intramurals is the Mr. & Ms. Intramurals, where selected students represent their grade level through modeling. 




  Ma'am Aki and Ma'am Kat, teachers from the MAPEH department, hosted the competition. "This is not just a pageant, this is not just a competition, this is the Mrs and Ms intramurals 2025!" Ma'am Aki said
  The nominated Mr. and Ms. Intramurals are:




  Prince Elord Antonio and Zoe Franchesca C. Bea,




  Rainne Gabriel Caampued and Jeiel Celeste A. SoÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ±as (Grade 10 Yellow Falcons),




  Andrei Josh R. Buctot and Dariella Lorraine Y. Trias, 




  Francis Allen D. Lora and Ella Mae L. Agabon (Grade 9 Red Phoenix),




  Jacob M. Suico and Nathaly Keith V. Ong,




  Christ Jared C. Lagumbay and Mheryerisz A. Dominguez (Grade 8 Blue Eagles),




  John Euno S. Calderon and Ma. Jhaneia Paula D. Diclito,




  Kit Jonas C. Santos and Vanie B. Dorado (Grade 7 Green Mockingjay).




  They modeled their school uniforms, followed by their sportswear.




  The modeling segment concluded with the announcement of the finalists who would proceed to the question-and-answer portion.




  The finalists announced were Prince Elord Antonio, Zoe Franchesca C. Bea, Rainne Gabriel Caampued, Kit Jonas C. Santos, Vanie B. Dorado, and Ma. Jhaneia Paula D. Diclito.




  Grade 10 representatives Ecko Laberinto and Daniel Niegas sang "Multo" during the intermission.




  Zoe Franchesca was asked a question, "In your opinion, does sport hinder studying, why?" And she answered, "My answer is no, because if you know how to manage time properly, then it will not be a problem."




  Vanie B. Dorado, one of the candidates, was asked a question, the question was "If you were to dedicate your victory to someone, who would it be and why?" She answered "That's a really interesting question, and I would love to answer that. If I would dedicate my victory to someone, i would dedicate it to other candidates and the DWNHS. this competition helps me boost my confidence."




  The competition is not just a competition, for them, it is a way to express themselves and to also boost their confidence. 




  The winners and runners-up were announced after the Q&A portion. 




  The judges, Mr. Jan Bonnel S. Buhain, Ms. Regina Angeline F. Patiag, and Mr. Llyod Figueras, chose the new Mr. and Ms. Intramurals.




  The Mr. Intramurals winner received a total of 4 awards, while the Ms. Intramurals winner received a total of 3 awards, in addition to their respective titles.




  Prince Elord Antonio from 10-Balite and Zoe Franchesca C. Bea from 10-Alagao, both representing the Yellow Falcons, were crowned Mr. and Ms. Intramurals 2025.  




  The 2nd runners-up are Kit Jonas C. Santos from 7-Loyalty and Vanie B. Dorado from 7-Charity, representing Green Mockingjay. 




  The 1st runners-up are Ma. Jhaneia Paula D. Diclito from 7-Wisdom and Rainne Gabriel Caampued from 10-Camachile.




  Prince Elord Antonio and Zoe Franchesca C. Bea won Best in Production Number and Best in School Uniform.




  Ella Mae Agabon and Kit Jonas C. Santos received the Netizen's Choice award.




  Prince Elord Antonio and Vanie B. Dorado won Best in Sportswear.




  The whole excitement of the crowd during this event is the most awakening time to show how supportive a student can be during this competitions.

The Championship Showdown between the Grade 7 Green Mockingjay and Grade 10 Yellow Falcons was a thrilling race-to-50 set.




The Mockingjay opened with a service ace, but the Falcons responded with back-to-back explosive attacks by Thalia Dela Cruz.




With the score at championship point, Salazar delivered a crushing service ace to seal the victory.




Thalia Dela Cruz was named tournament MVP after her unstoppable performance at the net.

articles.title: Women's taekwondo wows crowd at DWNHS Intramurals 2025
articles.excerpt: With every swift punch and every sharp kick, the women's taekwondo showcased discipline, skill, and artistry during the Intramurals 2025 at DasmariÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ±as West National High School on August 9, 2025

With every swift punch and every sharp kick, the women's taekwondo showcased discipline, skill, and artistry during the Intramurals 2025 at DasmariÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ±as West National High School on August 9, 2025.




In the individual poomsae category, Grade 9's Angel Barrios dominated as she scored 77, 56, and 19, giving her a total of 50.67 points, placing her first.




A close call from Grade 10's Juliana Macaraeg, with a score of 49 points, was followed by Grade 7's Fred Eline Ilano and Grade 8's Jaymee Joboco with 46.33 and 44.67 points, respectively.




During the pair poomsae division, Grade 9's Chaira Mae Esparagoza and Ariana Chelsea Dayrit clinched the gold medal with a total of 34 points.




The Grade 8 pair of Novy Orzel Maningat and Alexie Alera secured 2nd place, while Grade 10's Elaine Manalo and Rose Postrero placed 3rd, and Grade 7's Sydney Miles Lanciola and Alesandra Ugdiman came in last.




In the team poomsae category, the Grade 8 trio of Maningat, Alera, and Yhurika Jane Abriza acquired 31.25 points, bringing them to the top spot.




Grade 8 coach Ma'am Joice Drilon stood proud as she shared that she was very happy and proud not only because her athletes were able to compete, but also because they managed to secure 1st place.




Alera of Grade 8 expressed, "Nakakaba po kasi di po namin ine-expect na mananalo kami. Malalakas po sila, tsaka during the game kabado po kami, and nung lumabas po yung results, nagulat po kami."




The Grade 9 team of Esparagoza, Dayrit, and Bianca Ilagan fell short with a score of 30.50, while Grade 7's Lanciola, Ugdiman, and Shantal PreÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ±aredondo gained 28.25, and Grade 10's Manalo, Postrero, and Monica Louise Loquisan obtained 27.75 points.




In the freestyle segment, Grade 10's Macaraeg delivered a performance that earned her 49 points, claiming 1st place.




"Masaya po kasi first time ko po to, kasi sparring talaga ako, and nagtiis na lang ako. Siguro pagdating sa DIPSAA, mag-sparring ako," Grade 10's Macaraeg said after her win.




Grade 9's Barrios placed second with a score of 48.33 points, while Grade 8's Joboco earned 44.67 points, and Grade 7's Ilano scored 44 points.




The women's taekwondo highlighted both individual skills and teamwork, as participants across all grade levels demonstrated their precision, power, and pace during the Intramurals 2025.

articles.author: Ezevelle Junessa Matias

articles.title: Mockingjays Win DWNHS 3x3 Basketball Championship
articles.excerpt: Grade 7 Green Mockingjays triumphed over upperclassmen in DWNHS Intramurals 3x3 Basketball Boys held at San Antonio de Padua 1 Basketball Court on August 8, 2025.
articles.content:
Grade 7 Green Mockingjays triumphed over upperclassmen in DWNHS Intramurals 3x3 Basketball Boys held at San Antonio de Padua 1 Basketball Court on August 8, 2025.




With a score of 14-10, the Mockingjays sealed their championship win with a 4-point margin, relegating the Red Phoenix to runner-up.




The Mockingjays won their match against the higher-level Blue Eagles with a score of 16-15, a one-point lead.




Following their impressive performance, the stage was set for the ultimate showdown where they would face off against the ferocious Red Phoenix.




Camposano, a player from Grade 7 Diligence who scored 8 points in the championship game, shared that their daily training was what enabled them to reach the championship.




According to Camposano, the Mockingjays were ecstatic about their team's victory.




Their victory had a significant impact on both the team and the school.




Despite being freshmen in high school, they clinched the championship title.

The event kicked off with an individual demonstration, with Jace Dacillo of Grade 8 leading with a winning score of 28.6, followed by a score of 28.3 from Grade 10 performer Aaron James P. Margallo, and then a score of 24 by Grade 9 performer Clifford Aborot.




The players shined the brightest during the individual performance, the roars of each participant showing off their stances and forms.








The doubles demonstration went to the Grade 10 performers, Aaron James P. Margallo and Prince Dichoso, who clinched the winning score of 26.5, followed by the Grade 9 performers, M-Jhel Aquino and Zyder Acayang, with a score of 26.4, and the Grade 8 performers, Dan Zyrus Baluyot and Jobert Derecho Jr., with a score of 25.8.




According to Margallo, he felt sudden relief and was grateful because they did not expect to win first place.




"We had a short preparation, yet we still got the gold, and it's very fulfilling," he added.

coach, said that he was very grateful and happy at the same time because all of their hard work paid off.




"That silver, that gold, big ano na rin 'yan, basta very grateful for what happened. Happy rin ako sa performance ng boys and grateful na rin ako sa awards na ni-represent," he expressed.




Mr. Rhenz David from Far Eastern Polytechnic College, a coach and one of the judges, congratulated the students for their impressive performance and dedication. He also extended his gratitude for their participation in the Filipino martial arts, hoping that they will help broaden the reach of games made by Filipinos.

articles.title: Gugma wins all rounds, secures DIPSAA spot
articles.excerpt: Eathan Navarrete Gugma, a Grade 8 student and the defending champion, won all rounds in both rapid and blitz chess events and qualified for the upcoming DIPSAA tournament.
articles.content:
Eathan Navarrete Gugma, a Grade 8 student and the defending champion, won all rounds in both rapid and blitz chess events and qualified for the upcoming DIPSAA tournament.

A total of 31 participants from various grade levels joined the challenge, including nine grade 10, seven grade 9, 10 grade 8, and five grade 7 students.




Stated by the president, the participants have demonstrated each of their creativity especially in using art with recycled materials to make their bins.




Kenth added that "successful implementation would be marked by increased rates of accurate waste sorting and recycling, and increased public awareness of proper waste management practices."




On July 17, all the bins were submitted in the Science Laboratory room for the start of the judgement of the teachers to the bins.




As mentioned by Princess Vicada, the YES-O Vice president and the handler of this kind of challenge, the feelings she felt in this competition was a mixture of hesitation, overwhelm, and triumphant.

The Brigada Eskwela began with a motorcade featuring barangay vehicles, followed by the opening prayer led by Everson Gongora, president of the Supreme Secondary Learners Government (SSLG).




Gongora mentioned in his prayer the orientation to be bless, he added, "testiment of bayanihan," highlighting the collaboration of teachers, students, workers, and volunteers.




SPTA president Sir Laberinto delivered a speech, stating that Brigada Eskwela is a time when the school is prepared for the upcoming school year; he also shared the phrase "pagtutulongan ng mamamayan," emphasizing that Brigada Eskwela represents community unity.

The Zumba session began, led by the representative of Barangay Emmanuel Bergado 1. Following the activity, cleaning commenced with each barangay, department, club, and organization assigned to designated areas.




Volunteers cleaned classrooms, hallways, school grounds, and restrooms, repaired chairs and tables, and painted walls.




The president of the Filipino Club, Aya Villamor, shared, "It was a really fun experience since first time ko." She added that she did not realize how helpful the activity was, especially for those who will continue as students at DWNHS.




The work is not yet complete as Brigada Eskwela runs from June 9 to June 13, with remaining activities scheduled to continue on June 10.




The volunteers from earlier expressed anticipation for the improvements resulting from their work and are willing to volunteer again.




When asked about the benefits of volunteering, Sir Michael Lejarde responded, "Siyempre 'pag nag volunteer ka may sense of fulfillment na nakatulong ka." With 49 candidates running for various leadership roles, each presented their plans and reforms to implement.




The election process, held on February 25 and overseen by SSLG adviser Mr. Marvin Omboy along with the current SSLG officers, BKD Officers, and poll watchers.




Everson Gongora from 9-Boyle, representing the Bagani Partylist, secured the presidency with 578 votes.




"I want to thank everyone who voted for me as president. My priority is leading our school and meeting student expectations. I will keep my promises because, as they say, 'A promise means everything, but once broken, sorry means nothing.' Trust is hard to regain once lost," Gongora expressed with gratitude.




The newly elected officers are: President Everson Gongora, Vice President Princess Elaine Manalo, Secretary Frances Arrianne Osinsao, Treasurer Kyla Mae Gicanal, Auditor Samantha Arroyo, Public Information Officer Kylie Jane Moral, and Protocol Officer Precious Chloe Daep.




Grade-level representatives are: John Matthew Castro and Carl Marc Tulauan for Grade 10, Cyrus Jay Abejaro and Juriz Raffah Almera for Grade 9, and Akiko Noriko Kiskisan and Shamcey Tubigan for Grade 8.




After their victory, Gongora acknowledged that while they can not eliminate all issues, they will strive to reduce it.




According to the new officers, preparations for upcoming events and the implementation of their platforms for School Year 2025-2026 are already underway.




The new SSLG officers will officially assume their roles in S.Y. 2025-2026

articles.title: NASA Probe: Closest to Sun Ever
articles.excerpt: On the 24th day of December 2024, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) announced the record-breaking Parker Solar Probe's closest approach to the Sun.
articles.content:
On the 24th day of December 2024, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) announced the record-breaking Parker Solar Probe's closest approach to the Sun. 




The probe flew 3.8 million miles above the surface, creating a new record being the closest approach to the star.

With the closest distance to the star, the probe has recorded 3 types of sun's sound waves created by the solar winds such as Dispersive Chirping Waves, Langmuir Waves, and Whistler Mode Waves.




When these sound waves interact with Earth's magnetic field, Aurora skies occur and can be seen in some countries. However, these occurrences may cut power grids, electronics, and communication systems.




Astronomer Dr. Jenifer Millard noted that the probe must survive high temperatures, radiation, and cosmic dust from the Sun.




If successful , it will bring back data about the Sun's magnetic field which will help to understand the planets sitting between the magnetic field and the influence of life on Earth.




NASA's Parker Solar Probe continues to strive to eventually touch the Sun and open greater discoveries that will help our understanding of our solar system.

articles.title: Influencers on politics: A thread of threats
articles.excerpt: Stirring the pot for votes: politics is not a sprint, it's a long run.
articles.content:
Stirring the pot for votes: politics is not a sprint, it's a long run.  




      Commision on Elections (COMELEC) has recently closed filing of candidacy for the  national and local government elections for 2025. Many personalities, including some famous social media influencers, submitted their intent to run.




        A thread of socmed celebrities is transitioning into political roles for the 2025 Philippine Election, sparking a war of words. Some say it's their right; others disagree, saying it's a threat to the country.




     One of the SocMed celebrities that decided to file Certificate of Candidacy (COC) is Diwata, well-known for his Paresan business. can undeniably be of help to many. One is they can use their platforms to spread awareness of the important issues our country is facing to encourage them to act and participate. However, is this enough? What about the necessary qualifications (not those mentioned above that are according to the law) to be a leader, for instance, leadership experience?




        Before one decides to become a candidate in the upcoming election, it's necessary for him/her to know the right competencies to lead. Competencies that are acquired, not overnight, but through and in a long process.




      Just because one has the means to run, he/she will. Frustratingly, this has become a trend in the Philippine politics. People, even those with no related experiences and knowledge, file to become government officials. Hence, our politics becomes a big joke. I suggest that lawmakers have to amend the guidelines and requirements to qualify as candidates for election; they have to set them higher. Through this, we will have leaders who can actually lead, those who will not just sleep during hearings. 




      The Philippines is currently facing multiple problems, including unemployment, poverty, and environmental issues. Voting, based on popularity, will just worsen these. The Filipino people must be selective about who will lead the country. If we can scrutinous the qualifications for the minimum wage jobs, we, then, should be even more meticulous with our leaders.  




      Social media influencers and others who have been provoked by their fame to run for politics must be true to themselves about their readiness to take a very important and serious job of leading a nation. Integrated High School in the 3 vs 3 Basketball Girls.

articles.content:
Francisco E Barzaga Integrated High School triumphed over Salawag National High School, with a dominating score of 100-61 on October 29, 2024 at FEBIHS Basketball court.




Dimas a 15 year old, 5'10 hooper of FEBIHS shone the brightest in the game and led it with impressive 18 shots putting his team on spotlight.

Nepomuceno, EPS-I (MAPEH), participated. 




Dr. Nepomuceno reiterated the event's significance as a great opportunity for students inclined in sports to showcase their skills. 




DIPSAA will hold events on Volleyball (boys and girls), Badminton, Chess, Basketball (boys and girls), and Table Tennis; however, in other events like Futsal, Arnis, Taekwondo, Swimming, Dance Sport, and athletic games, different schools will directly play for the City Meet.




Dr. Francis Kenneth D. Hernandez, Principal of DIHS, proudly announced that their school, being one of the largest schools in the division, will send the most delegates for the City Meet. 




A breakout session was done to orient the coaches and other sports officials of the  schedules, venues, and other important matters about the games.




The division hopes that more students will join sports events as these also benefit them for their holistic development.

articles.title: Let the spotlight be his! He worked hard to get where he is right now. Please do not steal it from him!
articles.excerpt: Congratulations, Carlos Yulo! Thank you for bringing pride to the Philippines!
articles.content:
Let the spotlight be his! He worked hard to get where he is right now. Please do not steal it from him!




May he inspire all of us to never stop dreaming and believing. Your time to shine will come if you do not stop striving for excellence. 




Congratulations, Carlos Yulo! Thank you for bringing pride to the Philippines!

future.




Focusing on these proposals can shed light on their accountability and suitability as leaders. Choosing based on their platforms ensures the elected leaders have well-thought-out plans.




Nevertheless, a good proposal includes SMART criteria: Specific, with detailed plans and clear objectives on specific issues; Measurable, with goals that are quantifiable and objectively measured; Attainable, with achievable objectives, goals, and plans; Realistic, with well-crafted plans that acknowledge limitations; and Time-bound, with clear deadlines and efficiently tracked goals. The destruction happens because of the gravitational "tug-of-war" between the planet and the giant called tidal interaction. As the star evolves and expands, this interaction becomes stronger. 




"These interactions slow the planet down and causing its orbit to shrink, making it spiral inwards until it either breaks apart or falls into the star," Dr. Bryant explained.
